title: What are the best physical chemistry textbooks? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends. If you really want a fundamental understanding of physical chemistry, I'd skip the chemistry, initially, and get a sound understanding of the physics first. My vote for one of the best quantum mechanics books of all time is Principles of Quantum Mechanics by P. A. M. Dirac. If you're serious about getting a fundamental understanding, then you should consider reading some math books or taking some math courses. Beyond introductory calculus, I would consider learning ordinary and partial differential equations, linear algebra, probability theory, group theory, and real and complex analysis. That's a lot, but it's all important. I almost forgot. The calculus of variations shows up again and again in the theories of physics. Newton's laws can be formulated with the calculus of variations. The result is called Lagrange's equations. Nobody knows why the calculus of variations keeps showing up. Maybe there's some underlying unified theory yet to be discovered.

When I was a student 45 to 50 years ago, the most popular books (in India) were those by Samuel Glasstone. Some of his books are : 1. Textbook of Physical Chemistry, 2. Thermodynamics for Chemists, 3. Introduction to Electrochemistry, and 4. Theoretical Chemistry. Each one I still consider to be very very good. We also used to consult Daniels and Alberty , and the book by A J Mee. Mee's book I didn't like much. Taylor and Glasstone (Treatise on Physical Chemistry) was encyclopedic and I didn't consult the book till MSc. Later on I came across the book by Atkins . It is a good book but not as comprehensive as TBP by Glasstone. However, I have seen only its first edition. The first book on Quantum Chemistry that I read was by Walter Kauzmann. I found it very good. Pauling and Wilson was more popular . Eyeing,Walter and Kimball was a little more difficult. Later on I was suggested to read the book by Pilar ( Elementary Quantum Chemistry) . A wonderful book , it was not elementary as the name suggests. I also found 'Wave mechanics of atoms , molecules and ions' by Schutte a good book. The book by Szabo and Ostlund is also very good. I read it around 1986–87. I have not read Indian authors' books much. I have heard the book by KL Kapoor to be good. I am sorry I have not read it.

Physical Chemistry is all about the applications of the techniques and the theories of Physics to the studies of Chemical systems. Therefore, you need to have a deeper understanding of both chemistry and physics. In Physical Chemistry, you will be studying more about molecules and atoms. Now based on your objective you need to decide which textbook you want to study. Mostly Students who opt for PCM appear for IIT- JEE exams and students from PCB aspires for NEET exams. In both cases, we at Hellobachho recommends students to study from either OP Tandon or HC Verma for detailed explanation and qualitative questions to practice. Hellobachho is an e-learning institute who is dedicated to making students independent of any coaching institutes. Our students have become more confident as they get video lectures that they can watch at the convenience of their homes. This way students have more time for self-study and practice. In other cases like your personal interest and curiosity on this particular, we suggest going for Atkins' Physical Chemistry, by Julio de Paula, Peter Atkins. This is very well known among students who wish to pursue their long term career in Physical Chemistry. If you want to enroll in hellobachho courses then you could call us at 96670 94968 Mock test for free on hellobachho app All the Best!

A useful physical chemistry textbook and study guide with many solved problems is the following one :Schaum's Outline of Physical Chemistry (2nd Edition): Clyde Metz. Other good textbooks include :Atkins' Physical Chemistry, by Julio de Paula, Peter Atkins. Physical Chemistry, Understanding our chemical World, by Paul Monk. Introduction to Quantum Mechanics with Applications to Chemistry : Linus Pauling. This is a classic book about quantum mechanics and chemistry (or what became known as quantum chemistry ) .

Atkins physical chemistry: Amazon.co.uk: Peter Atkins, Julio de Paula: 9780199543373: Books It’s a mainstay in Pre-University reading. I bought an old edition because it was significantly cheaper and the reviews said it really wasn’t that important having the newest edition. I bought mine before I started my A-Level course and have delved into it a few times for some more deeper understanding of somethings but I must say I am not at a level yet, nor would it be wise for me to properly go through the book as my course has its own designated text (AQA chemistry A Level book).

Q: “What are the best physical chemistry textbooks?” There is no bad phys-chem book, all are really good. The main difference between various phys-chem books is their specific approaches to the subjects; some are more applied oriented and some more basic and fundamental, or statistical and computational approach is followed. Some books discuss the subjects at molecular and microscopic level and some are with macroscopic view. Thus, first you need to figure out your specific need, then select one of the several available phys-chem books.

The one that worked for me is Physical Chemistry by Peter Atkins and Julio de Paula. I like the way it’s written, but what is more important to me is that it has the right amount of colors and illustrations. Take in consideration I’m a undergraduate student, so there are probably books that are more detailed and complex, but I didn’t have the opportunity to discover them. :)

There are numerous books available to study/understand the Physical Chemistry. Every book has its own pros and cons. But I use Physical Chemistry by Peter Atkins. The language and elucidation in the book is candid and easy to understand (at least for me). P.S: I found this book best amongst other (I’ve read several other authors too), though they were good but the explanation given in this  particular book is very good. it isn’t mean that you also agree with my opinion. thanks.
Personally biased towards McQuarrie for Quantum Chem, Hill for Stat Mech and Peter Atkins for all in one.

1. “Physical Chemistry” by P. Atkins and J. de Paula 2.“Physical Chemistry” by I. N. Levine 3.“Physical Chemistry – A Molecular Approach” by D. A. McQuarrie and J.D. Simon 4. “Physical Chemistry” by David Warren Ball 5.” Physical Chemistry: A Molecular Approach ” by Donald A. McQuarrie I am not sure about quantum part. But these books are really helpful in research and higher studies in physical Chemistry. I hope this helps

The absolute best quantum chemistry text is McQuarrie's "Quantum Chemistry". It is clearly written, logically ordered, and asks you to derive much of the content yourself before it presents the result in small, bite-sized steps, which will do wonders both for your understanding of quantum chemistry and for your confidence in your ability as a budding physical chemist. This will probably be out of sequence for your course, which will probably cover thermo before quantum, but if you have time and interest it would be a very good idea to work through some of McQuarrie to convince yourself that this isn't a particularly difficult or confusing subject before Atkins can throw a wrench in the works. The original 1983 edition is probably best; the 2007 version relies heavily on numerical analysis programs, which is an unnecessary distraction in a first quantum course.

Donald McQuarrie has written a series of books ,most of which deal with aspects of physical chemistry.I'm most familiar with his book "Statistical Mechanics",which is OK-especially for an upper division undergrad course.Thus,I would send you to "Physical Chemistry-A Molecular Approach",by McQuarrie and Simon.

For physical chem - I did aakash modules and if my topic remained weak then I moved to other books like pradeep (I only did some specific topic wise examples and questions in between the text ) to make them better . I also did jee mains previous years ☺️ All the best ☺️☺️ Take care ☺️☺️

I am Chemistry student who was not exceptionally good at the Sciences before joining Bachelors course in Chemistry. So, during vacations, i decided to brush upon my concepts. The best book i found for Physical Chemistry was Physical Chemistry by Atkins and Paula. It can be a bit on the tougher side when you start reading it, but it’s really worth it. Hope it helps.

Good ,First of all, you’re clear in your mind that Solving numericals can improve your skill in physical chemistry.hmm..To improve your skills,you should be very strong in formulae,if at all someone wakes you up in the midnight and ask you any formula ,you should be able to tell the answer,next there is a book named R.C.MUKHERJEE available in the market .The chapter in this book starts with some small theory and then easy startup sums ,then medium level,then comes the highest level sums,there will be a fulfilled use of the book only when you do examples before the exercise,No doubt, it’s the best book for IIT-JEE,Mains and other competitive exams,If you solve the problems in this book ,You can solve any other problems ,in fact you can challenge your friends and teachers ,the reason behind is, this book covers each and every model,There is no model repetitive in this book. All the best.

looks like this is the book you are looking for > > > Quantum Chemistry After twenty-four years in print, Don McQuarrie has now updated his landmark "Quantum Chemistry". Perhaps the biggest change in the years since the first edition is the proliferation of computational chemistry programs that calculate molecular properties. McQuarrie has presented step-by-step SCF calculations of a helium atom in Chapter 9 and a hydrogen molecule in Chapter 10, in addition to including an entire chapter on the Hartree-Fock method and post-Hartree-Fock methods for the calculation of molecular properties. The book also uses problems to encourage the use of an invaluable National Institute of Science and Technology (NIST) website that lists experimental data and the results of various ab initio calculations for hundreds of molecules.
